commentBody: So long, Deb. I will dearly miss you. Your comments, instructions, and overall joy has really made me love crosswords. Best of luck in your future endeavors.

Deb, I wish all the best for your future endeavors and hope you have a great and fun time everywhere you go. I've loved your columns and more than the clues themselves, I've come back every day because it reads more like a friend telling me about their crossword solving strategy, like my mum used to when I was a child. Thanks for your time and words!

-30- for this venue, Deb. On to the next stage.
And a nice Friday puzzle to see you on your way.
All the best to you and your family, Deb.  You are a treasure and I will miss you...
I'll miss your writing quite a lot, Deb. Take care and God bless.
We'll miss you, Deb! I hope to find your writing in other venues.
I have enjoyed reading your comments; they always added to my enjoyment of the puzzles.

Deb, we will miss you, but don't miss us too much ;)

ARF and AIRKISSES made me laugh -- the latter I even got without any crosses, figuring I'd either be right or have a cute thing to post here.
Deb, we will miss you! Your columns have always been our favorite, and I wish you the very best in your new endeavors :’)

Deb, it’s always a pleasure to take a look at the author on these columns and see your name - it means it’s going to be a fun and witty wordplay commentary. All the best to you and thanks for the many great contributions over the years.

NOWWERETALKING.  This was afine fresh puzzle with fun entries that just rolled out one after the other.  One of those puzzles that ends too quickly. I loved VEGENAISE (new to me) sitting on top ENERGYBAR.  Trade blows for AIRKISSES gave me a smile.  And in the middle of the puzzle a member of the jazz aristocracy, Count BASIE, who could do so much with so few notes on the piano.

Deb, Thanks for giving a bunch of oddballs and ne’er-do-wells a place to feel at home. We’ll miss you and, as Liz B. said, hope to read you in other venues. Perhaps a juicy tell-all memoir about the cutthroat world of crosswording?  Cheers!
I forgot to add, farewell Deb.  Your wit, grace and intelligence have added so much to my enjoyment of my daily crossword since I started doing them on line.  You will be sorely missed.

I feel so accomplished that I solved this one with no hints! I also got upandatem with only one crossing letter (scene). Great puzzle! 

And BRAVO, Deb! I only got into this a year ago, but I'm glad I did so I could read your writing.

Last call for nominations for The 2025 Griddies!

Each year volunteers work to bestow awards on the year's best puzzles. Please read this message for information on how to nominate puzzles and how to vote for them.  Eric Hougland, Marshall Walthew along with yours truly will be coordinating this year's.

SCHEDULE:

December 11 - January 8: Nominations
1/11 - 1/16: Voting on First Round
1/18 - 1/25: Voting for Second (Final) Round 
2/1: Announcement of winners & runners-up

CATEGORIES:
 
Early week (M-W)
Thursday 
Friday-Saturday
Sunday

NOMINATIONS

You can REPLY to any message of this kind with your nominations. Nominations must include the puzzle date and constructor. NOTE that we already have a lot of nominations, so please only nominate your absolute favorites. 

VOTING

We'll use a custom-made ballot on an outside website. The ballot is easy to use and will allow for voting on each of the four categories. We’ll provide a link when voting begins. Nominating & Voting is open to all.

Ah, Deb. teaching us right up to the last. Today I learned that 
—30 — (dash thirty dash) is used in journalism to indicate the end of a story or dispatch, and originates from telegraph codes. 

It is also a symbol of new beginnings, which this most surely is. Best wishes in your retirement. You will be missed.
AIR KISSES to Deb, our Wordplay ENERGY BAR.  WHAT IS ART? Her ability to elucidate, encourage, and amuse.  THEY SAY she’ll be a hard act to follow!
Deb, thanks for all your insight and humor. You are truly a legend and have left your mark on the crossword world. I and so many of the rest of us will miss you, you have huge shoes to fill
I’ll miss seeing your byline and reading your columns.  I wish you lots of chocolate to nibble as you decide on your next adventures.  All the best in life to you, and your family.

Deb, you have been my favorite commenter all the time I've been playing the Crossword. I'll miss you. 
Best wishes for your future pursuits!
Re the mini's kangaroo movements: Consider  "Boink."
A surprisingly easy Friday puzzle for me. Maybe I was on the same wavelength or something…
Happy trails, Deb. We will miss you!

Thank you, Deb, and best wishes!  I started puzzling as a distraction from the pandemic and I doubt it would have been any more than that for me without your joyful, inspiring columns.  It won't be the same without you, but you got me hooked and I won't be quitting anytime soon!

Wishing you smooth skies ahead Deb!  It was a real pleasure to read your column and improve my solving skills.  You gave us all a boost with insightful and encouraging commentary.  

I reviewed my early days of solving in 2018-19, when I could only finish Monday and Tuesday without help.  Now I can usually get through every day, even if it takes me awhile.  Thanks for all your guidance!
Best of luck to you Deb!!

Why does a feast have to be meaty? 
Have I missed something??
Deb, You’ve been my teacher since I started five years ago. I’ve admired your willingness to speak with your own voice. That’s a great quality in a teacher — and in life. Best wishes to you

If my Havanese ate a habanero he would say neither Ola (and I guess Obama wasn't the author of the quotation either, though it did sound like him) nor Arf. No. More like HACK HACK HACK. 

(I had HAWK briefly, since both the raptor as well as certain hawkish politicians, Pentagon and media figures are threats to security.)

I like some of the combos: boons/tax returns; self esteem / internet famous (there are many on social media whose self esteem is entirely dependent on their internet famousness or at least the "likes" they garner); vegenaise / energy bar; tepee/res; Now we're talking / they say (I guess now they're talking, too).

I didn't know "Capotes" but if a bull came after me, I'd flap my "In Cold Blood," "Breakfast at Tiffany's" and "Answered Prayers" at it!

Thank you for your service, Deb.

True champions know when their goals have been achieved and leave on their own terms.   You have been a champion of the crossword entertainment genre,  emerging solvers and civil discourse within the solver community.  

Wordplay has been a rare comfortable corner of the internet and we appreciate your diligence in nurturing its evolution.  You leave it in good hands.

Hopefully you continue your work here as a more than occasional member of the commentariat.

I will miss you and your enlightened comments which always make my day.  Good luck with whatever adventure comes next.
Cheers
Antonietta Austin
Best Wishes and Biuquets if Gratitude!

Deb, I will greatly miss your puzzle help, your humor, your advice, & your forum moderation. Remember when you had to approve my clue for “algae” as “pond ___” (rhymes with chum ) that had been blocked by the forum filter?
I hope you find a new pursuit that’s just as fulfilling. I’ll have to get by without you somehow.

Bye, Deb.  

We'll miss you.

I hope you love retirement as much as I do.

Best wishes, Deb! I echo the kind words offered here from many of our favorite posters. When I was a newbie in 2020, your columns made me feel welcome with your signature wit, clarity, and encouraging words. You will truly be missed. Today’s puzzle was a fitting send-off by two great constructors. Thank you Adam &  Rafael!

Thank you, Deb. I started doing these puzzles in the Times on a regular basis in the fall of 2017. Your guidance got me used to all the idiosyncrasies of the NYT puzzle week. I came to appreciate rebuses and weird Thursdays because you showed me how to like them. Best wishes in your non-NYT life!

Deb,  Thank you for your years of insights into solving, your constant support to get us to believe in our solving abilities, and your many very interesting and entertaining columns.
Enjoy your retirement and believe me, you will find that you seem to actually have less time than when you worked.  Best of luck!

The puzzle was a very approachable Friday entry.

WHATISART?
Wagner and Musa, Amien!

Dear Deb,
It is your skill, your charm, your wordplay.

It is your patience as you led us through grids of discovery, joy, hope, and conquest.

It is your ability to reach solvers at all levels, with kindness and humor.

The year 2026 will no doubt provide new enchantments, but none as warm as your column.

Hope you visit us now and then!

Deb, 

We'll miss you.  Take care and have fun in your next adventure!
Peggy P

Wishing you the very best, Deb. You helped me reconnect with my love of crosswording during the pandemic, and here we are! 

I’m now working on my goal to solve the entire NYT digital archive. I’ve made it back to 2015 so far. Cheers!

Good luck in your new beginning, Deb. Although it’s such a loss for us, I know this is the start of something fabulous for you—cream always rises to the top. 

What a great Friday puzzle. Thanks, Adam and Rafael.
Thank-you for keeping it fun.
15:30. Enjoyed this one

I think this was the first, and probably last, time I've ever finished a puzzle by typing in an "X".

The cross and DAX and XYLEM was brilliantly devilish.

Congrats on your retirement and good luck!

P.S. there's a typo in the clue for 3-Down. An extra 'that'.

Deb, I will really miss your columns--kind, funny, generous, smart, encouraging--you've helped me go from a Monday-only solver to an all-week solver whose favorite day is Friday. I'm afraid my times and streaks will both slow down without your perfect selection of hints when I get stuck, but you've taught me not to be afraid to look things up and just have fun.  I hope you will have time for lots of both in your new adventures.  Thanks for your wonderful company all these years.

Normally my mom helps me with the crosswords, but she has been indisposed with the flu; hospitalized, as so many others are right now. But as I was stuck on a [Dance step also known as a backslide], I asked her nurse and they knew the answer without missing a beat.

I can’t do these without you just yet. You’re getting better, but you’re not over the hump quite yet. Hang in there for me.

Happy New Year, stay safe everyone.

Love you Deb. Your tone in Wordplay kept me here, as my skills increased. You got me through marital infidelity. Covid. Deaths. One of my lifelines is this silly puzzle every day. Now I think I’m a lifer! Best wishes for your next puzzle. I don’t think they ever stop!

It's been a pleasure to read your columns since I discovered them many years ago. You'll be a hard act to follow. Best wishes for your next phase. Oh, the puzzle. It was a fairly smooth solve. Though my trivia brain sees Tolstoy and a question mark in a title and can't help reaching right to Seinfeld and this question. https://youtu.be/qqS1Ty79mOE?si=7QPdwf4IJ680dwjm
All the best to you, Deb.
So long, Deb. Going to miss you.

Best wishes, Deb!

You say you love writing; well I love your writing (and you). Your columns always had the right mix of humor, encouragement, and entertainment. (note the Oxford comma—take that NYT).
Wow, Deb, I'll miss your gentle prods and clever humor. Change is good, though. May the new road rise up to meet you.
Aww don't go!
3D: Now that that is an answer I don't recall ever seeing before!

Long time lurker, first time commenter! Deb, I’m so so grateful for your presence as the Wordplay Sherpa. You’ve made this daily ritual much more enjoyable and your encouragement has made me fall in love with puzzles. All the best in your next chapter!

Wishing you the best @Deb on your next phase in life. As I closed out today’s puzzle and checked my stats, I reflected how many times you have aided me in keeping this streak alive since 2019 when I began this journey. 2399 days and counting…

All change is good and necessary - and nothing lasts forever…

- Lone Rider

Loved it. Lots of disambiguating and misdirecting across the grid.

REBATE before RETURN before REFUND.

TARO before TORO.

Cheers.

So happy to see VEGENAISE, my favorite condiment!

Also joining in the chorus of respect and gratitude to Deb. Thank you and wishing you all the best!

Deb,

Your puzzling commentary has always clued us in on so much, helping us out with crosswords (but never with cross words). Anyway, I just column like I see 'em.

In all seriousness, you have helped foster such a positive, effervescent community here, and I cannot thank you enough for what you have helped craft. 

You have led with such steadfast compassion over the years, making this silly word-loving nerd feel less alone in his pursuits. I thank you immensely for the kindness you have shown us all.

I wish you nothing but the very best in your retirement. May all the whimsy and wonderful (or punderful) wordplay of this world continue to be yours!

(Oh, and my bike just got a flat. Now I'll also have to re-tire.)

Deb,

Reading your columns on Thursdays and Fridays has been like hearing the voice of a crossword friend.  Thanks for bringing your insight, humor and encouragement to Wordplay. You've made this corner of the puzzling world a warm and welcoming place.

Wishing you all the best. 
XOXO

doesnt 3D have one too many "that"s?
if so, i fear for the continued punctiliousness of the clue editing.
id love for someone to tell me im mistaken.
Deb, I’ll miss your quirky wit and light. One of my favorite poems by Judith Viorst sums up my wish for you. https://face.wordpress.com/2005/09/21/the-sweetest-of-nights-and-the-finest-of-days/
Boo Hoo. Big boys DO cry.

Fare thee well, Deb. We’ll miss your humor, your words of encouragement, and your guidance in steering us to the confidence we need to solve the New York Times crossword puzzle on the REG.  

Best wishes to you on your journey. You will be missed. 🥲

That was though but enjoyable, except the SE corner, where the fill utterly stumped me, and I only managed to resolve it with lookups. My only gimmes around there were DAX and AMINO. PAM came to me, in the end - I remember kind commenters telling me about it here before. Thanks! (Poles don't have any kitchen sprays, that I know of, and I'm a home cook). The clue for MONOGAMY was cool.

However, all the rest of the fill there was arcana, to me.

I had entered UP AND AT it. Many of the other clues around there were complete mysteries to me, and having two wrong crosses defeated all my efforts to handle that corner on my own. UP AND AT 'EM... Ok. That makes sense, but I didn't know the expression.

All I know about improv is "Yes, and?" (thank you, "Lucifer") and that Americans generally consider it cringey (that's how it was presented in all the movies and shows I have ever seen, anyway). I don't even like proper theater, so an improvised version sounds horrific indeed. I thought the answer to A-a-a-and might be e-e-ENd 🤷🏽. I don't think Poland even has any improv, and if it does, I've luckily never experienced it.

I don't care about any brands of anything, and I'm not familiar with most Polish brands of supplements, let alone American ones.

Ditto celebrants - all I remember is that you celebrate your moms on another day than we do - it's May 26th here. I thought not only the day but also the month was different for you.

And finally, XYLEM... Yeah nah.
Good luck on your next gig. Thanks for your interesting comments.

When my doctor retired, I lost a friend, a mentor, an educator, a parent figure, a consoler, and, of course, a healer.  People in our lives who fill this role, even though we don't spend in-person time with them outside of that one arena, come to seem like part of our family.

When they leave, we lose a part of our team, the people who provide the glue that keeps us together, and we feel it on a personal level.  

Others will step in to keep the column healthy and supported, but it won't be the same.  We will miss everything you have so skillfully done for us.  Thank you, Deb, for being our family doctor (so to speak) for all this time.

Mainly came here to say thank you and all the best in your retirement, @Deb Amlen! You will be sorely missed. 
Adam and Rafa - nicely done and congrats on triple collab accomplishment.

Godspeed Deb! I have come to think of you as a welcome fellow traveler in the ways of crossed words. Some people just get the magic, and some just don’t. Thank you for being a treasured part of the NYT experience.
Awwww, Deb! Thank you for all the joy and wit you've been bringing us all this time. I hope you're going to drop by and bring us more smiles every once in a while!

First, I wish Deb Amlin wonderful new adventures! Second, I just started working on crossword puzzles in earnest. My initial reaction is I wish they were more vocabulary-knowledge games and less figuring-out-the-clue games.

Thank you very much Deb. 

I solved for many years in the paper. I only became aware of this forum with the move to the app. As such I’m newish here. A big part of being willing to engage was the style of the column. It’s always been interesting and engaging for all levels. 

Enjoy the next chapter
I hope you can be one of the celebrity columnists from time to time! Good luck on your new adventures!

There once was a woman named Deb
Whose prose snared us all in her web.
With a style deft and droll,
She has tickled our souls,
And her exit will leave us bereft!

Godspeed in all that comes next, Deb!  Thank you for all that you've given us.

Good luck Deb, and have fun! I wish you many more crosswords but never any cross words and I hope you never cross swords!

Thought for the Day:
A gimme and a natick make for a natty gimmick. 

(Sorry for my crazy posts recently, I’ve just fallen in love and I’m head over heels!)

All best wishes for your next adventure, Deb. Thank you for your column.

And thanks also to Adam and Rafael. Most enjoyable.

Deb, I have to add my voice to the many others who have expressed their appreciation for your contributions over the years. If this is “the nicest place on the internet”, it is largely because you have made it so! Your humor and especially your kindness will be very much missed. Sincere wishes for much joy in your future endeavors.

Enjoyed this puzzle’s collaboration. How many had ObAMa before ADAMS? (My hand is up!)

Glad I could get the puzzle over quickly so I could rush to read the column today. I’m very glad to have picked up solving crosswords again and this column has helped me immensely. Many thanks to Deb and all other writers here, and well wishes :)

You will be missed! 
Your column through the past few years has got me through the “I only do Monday to Wednesday” phase to “I do the whole week”!
One of my favourite parts of my morning puzzle routine has always been reading your tips, clues, and frankly encouragement to carry on. 
Best of luck and do come back as a celebrity guest writer!

Thank you, Deb! It's been a pleasure and a revelation.

See you on Facebook?


As for today, one can't help wondering if "War and Peace" would have been as popular if he had kept the original title, "War, What Is It Good For?" (Absolutely nothing!)

Regarding 22A, years ago I was working on a public assistance case in which my client refused to obtain a Social Security card, reasoning that the universal numbering system was somehow the Mark of the Beast. (Yes, there are many peculiar ideas out there.) You can imagine how tickled I was to learn that in such a case our state would simply assign an SSN-formatted identification number, starting with, I kid you not, 666.

Dear Deb,
You embody a certain spirit, and that is the reason so many have sent you such heartfelt wishes. Our hope will not die, and we cling to this oasis of humor, intelligence and kindness for dear life!
I too only dared the NYT xwords thanks to your „How to…“ article. It has been a cherished ritual ever since.
All the best!

Deb—

Thank you for your steadfast humor and tremendously helpful advice. I’ve learned a lot about the nuances of crosswords through your notes, the constructors’ notes, and the conversations in this marvelous community. This crowd will miss you, for sure, but most all, I think I am not alone in wishing you all the best as you venture on. Take care, be well, and good luck!
Thanks Deb, and congratulations. As I've found, retirement rocks! The pay ain't so hot, but everything else is really really good.

Deb — Really hate to see you go, but hope you enjoy retirement as much as I do. Without your enthusiasm and encouragement I probably wouldn’t have persevered in my 15+ years crossword journey and would have had an unknown void in those and future years. In my early times when stuck on puzzles, my look-ups relied on your mantra, “it’s your puzzle and you can do with it what you want”! Thanks for your excellent introductions, as I always looked forward to Thursdays and Fridays!

OH NO!!!  Who is going to make me smile,  shake my head in amazement--and fill my early mornings with enlightenment and humor?
Best of all to you Ms. Amlen; you've filled my golden years with so much. 
Thank you.
Best of luck in your new ventures, Deb. You will be missed here.

Thank you Deb for all the years you have helped me with the tough puzzles with your humor and crosswordese expertise. I have always enjoyed when you shared personal anecdotes. You felt like a secret friend. And thank you for your most important crossword lesson: the puzzle is for my enjoyment to complete however I need. I can look up an obscure actor's name or the 3rd high prince of Egypt if I need one less stressor on an already stressful day. I retired one year ago and love it. Can read 2 books at a time now and have more time foall my NYT puzzles. So thank you Deb and good luck with the next stage of your life!😊

Deb, you’ve been a heart warmer from the get-go.  Somehow that just happens from reading your words.  It’s your nature.  Everyone feels good around you.  You’ve also been brilliant in forming and tending to this forum – you set the civil tone for it, and when nastiness appeared, you disarmed it with your humor.  There are few such forums that feel as welcoming and respectful, and it’s because of you.

I will miss you greatly, and now that you will become a civilian, how about dropping in here occasionally or regularly?  I hear it’s a very nice place!

Dear Deb—(can I call you Deb?, it’s what I call my sister)—-I am so sad to hear that you won’t be here in this link anymore to help me with the tough solves and to guide my appreciation of the nuances of the Times Crossword. But, also very happy for you to start your next adventure.  I hope our paths cross again. You will be so missed !
No words can express how much your words have brightened my life during these tough times. Looking forward to finding out your next chapter. Congratulations and much thanks.
We will miss you, Deb! Come back anytime--you'll always be welcomed here!

“Hopefully, that lightness of spirit has made it easier for new solvers to learn, and for everyone to see crosswords can be a lot of fun.”  Deb you succeeded completely!  Good luck in all your future interests!

I will miss your byline, Deb,  here at NYT Games and your wit. Fully embrace all your new adventures and continue to learn in your retirement. 

Be well!

Deb, all the very best to you. Thanks for your contribution to this community! It’s really the best corner of the internet. 

(Quick shout out to Adam and Rafael who had a lovely puzzle, overshadowed by other news! Thanks for a nice Friday!)
Thanks, Deb for a fabulous column and finding so much commentary on the hobby we all love. Best wishes.

Blowing you an air kiss from afar, Deb. Thanks for turning me into a resourceful solver. I will forever think of you when I get stuck and remind myself to take a break and walk away, so my brain can process in the background. Never fails. Happy trails. 😚

Oh, the box was full of wit and humor today.  It’s a cliché, but I mean it: I didn’t want this to end.

Words that are normally dully clued were given spark, such as [Havenese greeting] for ARF, [Part of an underground network] for ROOT, and [Make some introductions, say] for EMCEE.

Lovely answers to beautify the journey: DEIGN, GUILT TRIP, PURGE, UP AND AT ‘EM, I CAN’T LOOK, NOW WE’RE TALKING, CLUNKY, and INTERNET FAMOUS (these last three are NYT answer debuts).

And wit?  The “liked” in [Extemely liked?] for INTERNET FAMOUS, as in the “like” you press on some social media sites?  Mwah!  (Thank you, Rex Parker, for pointing this out.) 

Enough bite to satisfy my brain's workout ethic, but also plenty of whee!-splats – fun and satisfying.  

I even liked the mini-story of SELF ESTEEM going downward and landing in a mild epithet.

In short, Adam and Rafael, a FEAST.  The synergy of your first themeless collab is marvelous.  More please, and thank you for a splendid outing!
I thought windfalls were burps so I got off on the wrong foot. HNY to all my readers!

Deb --

Words cannot express.

Pun intended!

Deb, I knew this day was coming, but now that it's here I'm crying real tears. I can't say you were my mentor, because I started doing these puzzles long before Wordplay existed. But I looked forward to every Thursday and Friday column with joy that I don't feel for the others, fine writers though they. I feel as if I know you, as if we'd could have been friends in real life, kinda heimish, y'know? I will miss your wit, your warmth, your bits of personal observations, so many things. 

I've said it before and will say it again: Wishing you many years of happy and healthy retirement. If your recent trip is any indication of your future plans, you will have a ball. And deservedly so.

We don’t have a TANDOOR in our house.  All of ours are white.




Et tu, emu.
You'll be missed for sure. Here's to your new ventures :)
Re 54A, I'm prepared for when "aquafaba" shows up.

Deb -- I started crosswords during the pandemic, and your witty column helped me through some of the tough clues, but made me laugh during a trying time. Thanks for the joy that you have brought!

Hopefully I'll "see' you on Social Media, or meet you for a Pastel de Nata at Portuga (my treat!).

Best wishes to our departing columnist.

Extremely well-made Friday puzzle. All sorts of interesting entries and clever clues. Not too difficult a solve for me by Friday standards, but not a cakewalk (or a MOONWALK) either.

Was tricked into initially entering ROAST rather than FEAST for my "meaty meal", which slowed me down a bit. Also, I realized today that HABANEROS and JALAPENOS are identical in length and have identical vowel patterns (even though the former are much more "dangerous" than the latter).

A very fine Friday puzzle! And FIBONACCI too.
Deb- thanks for being the one who encouraged me to never give up on a puzzle. This has made my solving experience so much more fun. Will miss you.
Deb, so long, and thanks for all the chocolate.

@Lewis

I forgot to post my favorite clues yesterday, but I don’t think there was any overlap with yours! (I am easily amused)

Favorite clues of 2025:
* [Words before someone finally snaps?] SAYCHEESE 1/3/25 (Colin Adams)
* [Permanent location?] SALON 7/29/25 (Peter Gorman)
* [He might be carrying a big picture] LEAD ACTOR 8/3/25 (Jeremy Newton)

* [Felt something on your head?] FEDORA 10/29/25 (John Donegan)
* [People looking for hookups, informally] R V ERS 11/26/25 (John McClung)

Dear Deb,
I've followed your Wordplay column for all the years I've done the crosswords online. Even on a tough solving day, I always look forward to your humor and enthusiasm.
Wishing you all the best in your next phase of life. I'm sure it will be as much fun as your Wordplay stint.
cheers
md
So much fun for a first Friday of 2026!!!
Thanks for your companionship, may you continue to find joy in life.

Thank you Deb.

For your bright spirit, 
endless positivity,
infectious love for the puzzle,
eagerness and efforts to include all
in the joy of the solve,

and for making at least one 
nerdy oddball feel like she had
a friend in her iPad 
to chat with a few mornings 
every week.

Best wishes for all the good things!

Ah, yes.....if these two were in my classroom, I would seat them well apart.
I see they have spent most of their time concocting clever clues.  I solve them thusly:
Which of our Presidents would be so pithy and outspoken? Obviously, a post-war leader...short name....just get one crossing.... and Voila!
And so it goes. ...
But I would wish to have lived out my life without knowing there is such a thing as ...god help us!...a vegan substitute for mayonnaise.  Especially if spelt with just one N.
I CAN'T unsee it!

Deb,

Very good luck with whatever it is that's coming next. You've been a daily (nearly) pleasure (always) for years. And as I work my way through the Archives, you will be with me for years to come.

Thanks for it all!
Oof!

Thanks, Deb. I learned a ton from you about how to solve a puzzle. My biggest takeaway is to view the puzzle as an educational opportunity, so it's OK to look up who sang that song if I just can't remember. Thank you again.
So sorry to see you go, Deb. Thank you for your column, and best wishes on your new adventures.

@deb amlen

Thank you for the many years of laughs.  Some of my favorites include tales of the extremely spunky terrier, adventures in fermentation, and not letting the accusers bring you down ("It wasn't me", after all!)

Enjoy your new adventures and keep us posted on what you're up to.  We know it will be a worthwhile read!

PS Lovely tribute to you from this puzzle's constructors.

Deb! Thank you for everything you’ve done. Your columns are so much fun to read that I’ve kept clicking through even as my skills have improved to the point of rarely needing clues to complete the puzzles (my streak is over 1500 days!). You’ve been a great culture-setter, cheerleader, and anchor for this community. Wishing you all the best in this next chapter. We will miss you!
Best wishes, Deb. It's been swell reading you...

Will join the chorus - you will be greatly missed, Deb. Hard to imagine what this will be like without you. Thanks so much for all you've done for us. And... just a somewhat different kind of puzzle find today. A Sunday from April 18, 1993 by Norman S. Wizer with the title: "People with connections." Don't recall another one quite like this. Definitely one of the harder Friday puzzles in the past few years! I very much liked the toughness, which caused the solve to last a good deal longer than most Fridays. Lots of greats answers: VEGENAISE (new to me), HABANEROS, XYLEM, AIR KISSES, GUILT TRIP, WHAT IS ART?, I CAN'T LOOK, UP AND AT 'EM, INTERNET FAMOUS, FIBONACCI, among others.

Knew that FEAST is a hearty meal, of course ... but had not realized it was particularly "meaty". Did not know "on the REG" for frequently, or RES for a booking, or "try-hard" (a variant spelling of tryhard) for POSER (an uncool person, not a riddle).

Oh, and my usual late puzzle find. A Thursday from August 29, 1996 by Randolph Ross. Three 15 letter theme answers. Don't recall another one like this. Those "clues" and answers: 17a. "=____" NINETEENLESSTWO 34A. "=____" DOUBLESEVENTEEN 54A. "=____" TWOXTWENTYSEVEN Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=8/29/1996&g=54&d=A ....

A "keep the faith" puzzle, if ever I saw one.  Would I have to cheat on the Tolstoy title to complete the (for me) completely undoable NE?  I was sure I would -- but as it turns out, I solved this bear cleanly.

All I had in the NE was that the pepper was one of the EROS or ENOS.  They're all the same to me -- they burn your tongue and your throat and your esophagus and your nether regions and why would anyone subject themselves to that?  Every Mexican or Thai restaurant I call for delivery gets the same instruction: NO HOT PEPPER, PLEASE!!!  THANK YOU!!!  You can throw them out immediately, but they'll get on your hands and then, God forbid you touch your eyes.  Inventions of the Devil, I say.  Isn't one of them called a Diablo?

Back to the puzzle.  "Pithy putdowns" had to have an S as the second letter, so there went NAHS and NAWS and NOES.  Took me forever to see TSKS.  

Because I had no idea how to spell FIBONACCI, I had MOUNTAIN before MOONWALK for the dance.  I had CLUMSY before CLUNKY for cumbrous.  
Great clue for TAX RETURN -- which was one of the last answers to go in.

A wonderful Friday tussle: hard and rewarding, with all the crunch in the cluing and almost no trivia at all.  Loved it.

Actually, it was only a very mild Natick for me.

But why that cross wasn't a bad Natick is a huge mystery to me.  I had the "A" of DAX early.  It took me a while to get UPANDATEM, so the D came along later.

My brain felt ticklish with the DA_ like it knew it but couldn't quite find the right scrap of paper it was written on.

Meanwhile the _YLEM emerged from the mists.  

Suddenly I seemed remember Louis Rukeyser on Wall Street Week mentioning the DAX.  I watched this show when I was a grad studen, even though my annual gross income was completely incapable of buying even the tiniest market portfolio.  I thought watching it made me smarter about money.

At the same time, XYLEM must have somehow emerged from my chemistry background, the chemical xylene, which I recalled from my college days.  I always like xylene because it was such a cool aromatic molecule--two methyl groups attached to a benzene ring.  

But the biggest coolness was that because xylene, C8H10, had three, (and only three) distinct forms, that was powerful evidence that benzene was a six membered ring.  

I have no idea why I'm writing this other than it feels kind of good, kinda soothing, thinking back on those days when the world seemed so full of possibilities.

Feel free to guide me back to the correct wing of the institution.

@Andrzej 

Improv changed my life completely in my late 50s. Not the jokey kind of improv, but long-form Chicago style. Most people still use it primarily as a humor delivery method. I treat it more like improvised theater.

I say it changed my life, because improv serves as a way to speak truth safely. I feel compelled to speak truth, and polite society does not allow it. An improv scene does, whether on or off stage.

Monika Odzarska is a talented Polish improviser. She is in a duo with American Jeff Michalski. I saw them do a great show last October.

Having said all that, I will also say that I hate watching improv. It's almost always terrible.

I recommend learning and performing long-form improv to everybody, because, as I said, it allowed me to change my life. I wish I'd started doing improv when I was a kid. But not really, because then I wouldn't be who I am now.

TJ & Dave have some recorded improv sets on Vimeo that are, to me, improv at its best.

@Andrzej

I only got into improv because, as a then-filmmaker, I wanted to meet actors.

Before my first class, which I arrived at compulsively early (of course) I was speaking with the instructor about how much I don't like improv and my motivation, and he explained that what he teaches is not "Whose Line Is It Anyway", but that it more explores the human condition. I was intrigued.

At the end of the first class, the instructor said off-handedly that we'd be doing a show at the end of the class.

I did not know what to say! I can't do a show! Get on stage without a script?!?! No way! 

All my classmates seemed pretty psyched about it, but I informed them, sheepishly, that I would almost certainly not be able to perform in a show on stage.

Well, now I've done 100s of shows, and, while I don't enjoy watching improv, I do enjoy performing. If the audience doesn't like what I do, that's on them. I perform for me. My partner and I also do scenes at home all the time. It's fun ... and there is always truth, which is cathartic.

Improv gave me the confidence to approach life more freely. It also gave me the ability to fail publicly without wanting to literally die. (Okay, I'm still working on that, but I'm a lot better.) I quit drinking. I got out of a long-term relationship that I'd figured I was destined to die in.

Anyway, that's part of my story...
